00006 #include "trace.h"

00008 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00009 // C++ Support Functions (instead of using libstdc++) according to ABI 
00010 // (Application Binary Interface) for C++ programs that is the object code interface 
00011 // between user C++ code and the implementation-provided system and libraries.
00012 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00013 
00014 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00015 // Dynamic Shared Library (DSO) Handle. No shared libraries thus defined as dummy.
00016 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00017 extern "C" const void* const __dso_handle = &__dso_handle;
00018 
00019 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00020 // After constructing a global (or local static) object, that will require destruction on
00021 // exit, a termination function is registered with __cxa_atexit.
00022 // This registration, e.g. __cxa_atexit(f,p,d), is intended to cause the call f(p) 
00023 // when DSO d is unloaded, before all such termination calls registered before this one.
00024 // It returns zero if registration is successful, nonzero on failure. 
00025 // The registration function is not called from within the constructor. 
00026 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00027 extern "C" int __cxa_atexit( void (*func)(void*), void* arg, void* dso_handle)
00028 {
00029     TRACE_INFO( "__cxa_atexit: Foo=%08x, Arg=%08x\n", 
00030                 (unsigned int) func, (unsigned int) arg );
00031     return 0;
00032     }
00033 
00034 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00035 // Returns 1 if the initialization is not yet complete; 0 otherwise. This function is
00036 // called before initialization takes place. If this function returns 1, either 
00037 // __cxa_guard_release or __cxa_guard_abort must be called with the same argument. 
00038 // The first byte of the guard_object is not modified by this function. 
00039 // A thread-safe implementation will probably guard access to the first byte of the 
00040 // guard_object with a mutex. If this function returns 1, the mutex will have been 
00041 // acquired by the calling thread. 
00042 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00043 extern "C" int __cxa_guard_acquire( long long int* guard_object )
00044 {
00045     TRACE_INFO( "__cxa_guard_acquire: Obj=%08x\n", (unsigned int) guard_object );
00046     return 1;
00047     }
00048 
00049 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00050 // Sets the first byte of the guard object to a non-zero value. This function is called 
00051 // after initialization is complete.
00052 // A thread-safe implementation will release the mutex acquired by __cxa_guard_acquire
00053 // after setting the first byte of the guard object. 
00054 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00055 extern "C" void __cxa_guard_release( long long int* guard_object )
00056 {
00057     TRACE_INFO( "__cxa_guard_release: Obj=%08x\n", (unsigned int) guard_object );
00058     }
00059 
00060 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00061 // This function is called if the initialization terminates by throwing an exception. 
00062 // A thread-safe implementation will release the mutex acquired by __cxa_guard_acquire. 
00063 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00064 extern "C" void __cxa_guard_abort( long long int* guard_object )
00065 {
00066     TRACE_INFO( "__cxa_guard_abort: Obj=%08x\n", (unsigned int) guard_object );
00067     }
00068 
00069 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00070 // An implementation shall provide a standard entry point that a compiler may reference
00071 // in virtual tables to indicate a pure virtual function. This routine will only be called
00072 // if the user calls a non-overridden pure virtual function, which has undefined behavior 
00073 // according to the C++ Standard. Therefore, this ABI does not specify its behavior, but 
00074 // it is expected that it will terminate the program, possibly with an error message. 
00075 //---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00076 extern "C" void __cxa_pure_virtual( void )
00077 {
00078     TRACE_FATAL( "__cxa_pure_virtual: Fatal error\n" );
00079     do ; while( true );
00080 }
